'''Bobo Jenkins''' (January 7, 1916 – August 14, 1984)<ref name="Dead"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[Detroit blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. He also built and set up his own [[recording studio]] and [[record label]] in [[Detroit]].<ref name="AMG"/> Jenkins is best known for his [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] of "Democrat Blues" and "Tell Me Where You Stayed Last Night".<ref name="Dead"/>

==Biography==
He was born '''John Pickens Jenkins''' in [[Forkland, Alabama|Forkland]], [[Alabama]],<ref name="Dead"/> but when less than a year old his father, a [[sharecropping|sharecropper]], died and Jenkins grew up with his mother and uncle.  However, he left home before the age of 12, and arrived in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]]. He had a wife at the age of 14, the first of ten marriages. Jenkins took casual work in the  [[Mississippi Delta]] for several years and then enrolled in the [[United States Army]]. Following his 1944 [[military discharge]], he relocated to Detroit, working for [[Packard]] and managing a garage, before spending twenty seven years working for [[Chrysler]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p188318/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Bobo Jenkins |author=Reif, Fred |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref>

In the late 1940s Jenkins learned the guitar and starting writing songs. He penned the [[Politics of the United States|politically]] motivated "Democrat Blues" on [[United States|US]] [[Election Day (politics)|Election Day]] in 1952.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Guido
| last= van Rijn
| year= 2006
| title= The Truman and Eisenhower blues: African-American blues and gospel songs
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Continuum 
| location= London, England
| isbn= 0-8264-5657-X
| page= 102}}</ref> Therein Jenkins expressed his disquiet about [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] becoming the first [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] in the [[White House]] for almost twenty years.<ref name="Sunday">{{cite web|url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/tag/otis-spann |title=Big Road Blues |publisher=Sundayblues.org |date= |accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref>

With assistance from [[John Lee Hooker]], Jenkins [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] "Democrat Blues" in [[Chicago]] in 1954, which was released by [[Chess Records]]. A further issue appeared on Chicago's Boxer Records, and then "Ten Below Zero" (1957) on Detroit's [[Fortune Records]]. In 1959 he set up his own [[record label]], Big Star Records, whose first release was Jenkin's [[single (music)|single]] "You"ll Never Understand" and "Tell Me Where You Stayed Last Night." He met and played alongside [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], before self-constructing his own [[recording studio]]. He recorded mainly local musicians including James "Little Daddy" Walton, Little Junior Cannady, Chubby Martin and Syl Foreman.<ref name="AMG"/>

Jenkins went on to [[Promoter (entertainment)|promote]] the first Detroit Blues Festival in 1972, and the same year issued his first [[album]], ''The Life of Bobo Jenkins''.  The album became known as the "red album", due to the color of the [[record sleeve]].  It included a photograph of a younger Jenkins- who was 56 years old- within a star shape. This was a tie-in with the Big Star Records name.  Jenkins was one of the headline acts in the Detroit blues review part of the 1973 [[Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festival]]. Recordings from the festival were released by Schoolkids Records in 1995, which included two tracks by Jenkins. In 1974, Jenkins penned another song with political overtones, "Watergate Blues," which appeared on his next album ''Here I Am a Fool in Love Again''. It boasted the same cover design as the previous release, but with a change in color was alternatively dubbed the "green album". [[Session musician]]s used included [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]] based artists such as Sarah Brown, Fran Christina and  [[Steve Nardella]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1976 Jenkins performed at the [[Smithsonian Institution]], as part of the celebrations marking the [[United States Bicentennial|US Bicentennial]].

''Detroit All Purpose Blues'' was issued in 1977, his so-called "yellow album", which utilised other Detroit based blues musicians such as Buddy Folks and [[Willie D. Warren]]. In 1982, he went to [[Europe]] with the American Living Blues Festival [[concert tour|tour]], but due to poor health he returned home after his first [[concert]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Bobo Jenkins died in Detroit after a long illness in August 1984, at the age of 68.<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html |title=The 1980s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

==Discography==
===Albums===
*''The Life of Bobo Jenkins'' (1972) - Big Star
*''Here I Am a Fool in Love Again'' (1974) - Big Star
*''Detroit All Purpose Blues'' (1977) - Big Star
*''The Life of Bobo Jenkins'' (2003) - [[P-Vine Records|P-Vine]] (re-issue)<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/bobo-jenkins-mn0000064600/discography |title=Bobo Jenkins | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1984-08-14 |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thatsallritemama.blogspot.com/2009_03_01_archive.html |title=That's All Rite Mama: March 2009 |publisher=Thatsallritemama.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

===Compilation albums===
*''Motor City Blues'' (1973)<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.leisureclass.net/detroitrock/ |title=Detroit Rock and Roll |publisher=Leisureclass.net |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

*[[List of electric blues musicians]]

==Quotation==
{{cquote|I was workin’ out to Chrysler and I sat down at the end of the line and wrote that song, The whirrin’ of the machines gives me the beat. It’s like listening to a band play all day. Every song I ever wrote that’s any good came to me on the assembly line.}}
— Bobo Jenkins<ref>{{cite web |url=http://taubmancollege.umich.edu/architecture/about/chairs_message/ |title=Chair's message - Michigan architecture|author=Buresh, Tom J. |publisher=Taubmancollege.umich.edu|accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref>
